title: Nothing Like an SAT Score to Prove a College Counselor Wrong
sub_head: The test can help identify students who might otherwise be overlooked.
body:
Regarding Jason Riley’s “MIT Leads the Way in Reinstating the SAT” (Upward Mobility, April 6): Students from higher-income households tend to perform better on virtually all admissions criteria, not only the SAT and ACT. But the tests can help identify students who might otherwise be overlooked.
In 1964 I was applying to colleges. A counselor advised me not to bother with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. I ignored that advice. My next meeting with that counselor was to review my SAT scores. He looked at them in stunned amazement. I was probably one of those students who would have been overlooked without the SAT. I am still proud to be MIT class of 1969.
